comments.body:
The new wording calls the certificate chain an input to the DID resolution process, but later the document defines the chain as being provided via the `x509chain` DID resolution option (a comma-separated b64url string) and presumably decoded/parsed before policy evaluation. Please align this text with the later section by explicitly stating that `chain` in the Rego JSON input is the parsed chain derived from the `x509chain` resolution option (or otherwise clarify the actual API inputs). Also consider avoiding the ambiguous pronoun “they” by naming the fields being passed (`did` and `chain`).
```suggestion
The inputs to the resolution process are the DID string itself and the `x509chain` DID resolution option, which carries a comma-separated base64url-encoded X.509 certificate chain.
To evaluate the reference Rego code shown below, the DID and certificate chain must be passed to a Rego runtime as a JSON document: `{"did": "<DID>", "chain": <CertificateChain>}`, where `did` is the DID string and `chain` is the parsed representation of the certificate chain derived from the `x509chain` resolution option.
```

```suggestion
The inputs to the resolution process are the DID string itself and the `x509chain` DID resolution option, which carries a comma-separated base64url-encoded X.509 certification path.
```

```suggestion
To evaluate the reference Rego code shown below, the DID and certification path have to be passed to a Rego runtime as a JSON document: `{"did": "<DID>", "chain": <CertificateChain>}`, where `did` is the DID string and `chain` is the parsed representation of the certification path derived from the `x509chain` resolution option.
```

pulls.title: Add "Use of Identifier Contents" Security Consideration
pulls.author: copilot-swe-agent
pulls.body:
Addresses the need for guidance on safely handling did:x509 identifier strings that embed certificate chain elements.

### Changes

- Added new subsection to Security Considerations explaining:
  - did:x509 identifiers encapsulate certificate chain elements (CA fingerprint, subject names, SANs, EKUs)
  - Using identifiers as opaque handles when externally endorsed (e.g., via VC) is acceptable
  - Parsing identifier components for authorization without resolution is insecure
  - Attack vector: crafted identifiers with arbitrary values that don't correspond to legitimate chains

### Key guidance

> Implementers MUST NOT parse or interpret individual components of the identifier string for authorization decisions unless the identifier has been resolved against a verified certificate chain.

pulls.title: Add Rego syntax validation to checks.yml pipeline
pulls.author: copilot-swe-agent
pulls.body:
Issue #15 tracks validation of code snippets embedded in the spec. ABNF, CDDL, and JSON were already covered—this adds Rego.

### Changes

- **OPA installation**: Download latest OPA binary using the openpolicyagent.org latest link
- **Rego Compliance step**: Concatenate extracted `figures/rego/*.rego` with package declaration, run `opa check`
- **`.gitignore`**: Exclude generated artifacts (`figures/`, `all.abnf`, `all.rego`)

### Rego validation logic

```bash
echo "package didx509" > all.rego
cat figures/rego/*.rego >> all.rego
opa check all.rego
```

The Rego fragments in the spec define `parse_did`, `valid`, and `validate_predicate` rules that must be concatenated to form a valid policy. The pipeline will fail if Rego files are missing from the extracted figures.
